qas.question: How does the expression of genes encoded in DNA begin?

answers.text: by transcribing the gene into RNA
a second type of nucleic acid that is very similar to DNA

qas.question: What base does RNA have in place of thymine?
What specifies the correspondence between codons and amino acids during protein translation?

context: The expression of genes encoded in DNA begins <a0_0>by transcribing the gene into RNA<a0_0/>, <a1_0>a second type of nucleic acid that is very similar to DNA<a1_0/>, but whose monomers contain the sugar ribose rather than deoxyribose. RNA also contains <a2_0>the base uracil<a2_0/> in place of thymine. RNA molecules are less stable than DNA and are typically single-stranded. Genes that encode proteins are composed of <a3_0>a series of three-nucleotide sequences<a3_0/> called codons, which serve as the "words" in the genetic "language". <a4_0>The genetic code<a4_0/> specifies the correspondence during protein translation between codons and amino acids. The genetic code is nearly the same for all known organisms.:4.1
